segment.source: BCDEdit is a command-line tool for managing Boot Configuration Data (BCD).
segment.target: BCDEdit is a command-line tool for managing Boot Configuration Data (BCD).

segment.source: BCDEdit is a command-line tool for managing Boot Configuration Data (BCD).
segment.target: BCDEdit is a command-line tool for managing Boot Configuration Data (BCD).

segment.source: BCD files provide a store that is used to describe boot applications and boot application settings.
segment.target: BCD files provide a store that is used to describe boot applications and boot application settings.

segment.source: BCDEdit can be used for a variety of purposes, including creating new stores, modifying existing stores, adding boot menu options, and so on.
segment.target: BCDEdit can be used for a variety of purposes, including creating new stores, modifying existing stores, adding boot menu options, and so on.

segment.source: You'll need administrative privileges to use BCDEdit to modify BCD.
segment.target: You'll need administrative privileges to use BCDEdit to modify BCD.

segment.source: Start the Command Prompt (Admin) or use Windows PE.
segment.target: Start the Command Prompt (Admin) or use Windows PE.

segment.source: A normal shutdown and reboot is necessary to ensure that any modified BCDEdit settings are flushed to disk.
segment.target: A normal shutdown and reboot is necessary to ensure that any modified BCDEdit settings are flushed to disk.

segment.source: BCDEdit is included in the %WINDIR%System32 folder.
segment.target: BCDEdit is included in the %WINDIR%System32 folder.

segment.source: BCDEdit is limited to the standard data types and is designed primarily to perform single common changes to BCD.
segment.target: BCDEdit is limited to the standard data types and is designed primarily to perform single common changes to BCD.

segment.source: Some common BCD operations, such as recovering a partition or setting up a new PC's system partition, may be more easily accomplished by using BCDboot.
segment.target: Some common BCD operations, such as recovering a partition or setting up a new PC's system partition, may be more easily accomplished by using BCDboot.

segment.source: For complex operations or nonstandard data types, consider using the BCD Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) application programming interface (API) to create more powerful and flexible custom tools.
segment.target: For complex operations or nonstandard data types, consider using the BCD Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) application programming interface (API) to create more powerful and flexible custom tools.

segment.source: The following command-line options are available for BCDEdit.exe.
segment.target: The following command-line options are available for BCDEdit.exe.

segment.source: Displays a list of BCDEdit commands.
segment.target: Displays a list of BCDEdit commands.

segment.source: To display detailed help for a particular command, run bcdedit /?command, where command is the name of the command you are searching for more information about.
segment.target: To display detailed help for a particular command, run bcdedit /?command, where command is the name of the command you are searching for more information about.

segment.source: Creates a new empty boot configuration data store.
segment.target: Creates a new empty boot configuration data store.

segment.source: The created store is not a system store.
segment.target: The created store is not a system store.

segment.source: Exports the contents of the system store into a file.
segment.target: Exports the contents of the system store into a file.

segment.source: This file can be used later to restore the state of the system store.
segment.target: This file can be used later to restore the state of the system store.

segment.source: This command is valid only for the system store.
segment.target: This command is valid only for the system store.

segment.source: Restores the state of the system store by using a backup data file previously generated by using the /export option.
segment.target: Restores the state of the system store by using a backup data file previously generated by using the /export option.

segment.source: This command deletes any existing entries in the system store before the import takes place.
segment.target: This command deletes any existing entries in the system store before the import takes place.

segment.source: This command is valid only for the system store.
segment.target: This command is valid only for the system store.

segment.source: This option can be used with most BCDedit commands to specify the store to be used.
segment.target: This option can be used with most BCDedit commands to specify the store to be used.

segment.source: If this option is not specified, then BCDEdit operates on the system store.
segment.target: If this option is not specified, then BCDEdit operates on the system store.

segment.source: Running the bcdedit /store command by itself is equivalent to running the bcdedit /enum active command.
segment.target: Running the bcdedit /store command by itself is equivalent to running the bcdedit /enum active command.

segment.source: It does not persist across reboots, and is only used in cases where the system store device is ambiguous.
segment.target: It does not persist across reboots, and is only used in cases where the system store device is ambiguous.

segment.source: Operating on entries in a store
segment.target: Operating on entries in a store

segment.source: Makes a copy of a specified boot entry in the same system store.
segment.target: Makes a copy of a specified boot entry in the same system store.

segment.source: Creates a new entry in the boot configuration data store.
segment.target: Creates a new entry in the boot configuration data store.

segment.source: If a well-known identifier is specified, then the /application, /inherit, and /device options cannot be specified.
segment.target: If a well-known identifier is specified, then the /application, /inherit, and /device options cannot be specified.

segment.source: If an identifier is not specified or not well known, an /application, /inherit, or /device option must be specified.
segment.target: If an identifier is not specified or not well known, an /application, /inherit, or /device option must be specified.

segment.source: Deletes an element from a specified entry.
segment.target: Deletes an element from a specified entry.

segment.source: Creates mirror of entries in the store.
segment.target: Creates mirror of entries in the store.

segment.source: Deletes a specified element from a boot entry.
segment.target: Deletes a specified element from a boot entry.

segment.source: The /enum option is the default value for BCEdit, so running the bcdedit command without options is equivalent to running the bcdedit /enum active command.
segment.target: The /enum option is the default value for BCEdit, so running the bcdedit command without options is equivalent to running the bcdedit /enum active command.

segment.source: Usually, any well-known entry identifiers are represented by their friendly shorthand form.
segment.target: Usually, any well-known entry identifiers are represented by their friendly shorthand form.

segment.source: Specifying /v as a command-line option displays all identifiers in full.
segment.target: Specifying /v as a command-line option displays all identifiers in full.

segment.source: Running the bcdedit /v command by itself is equivalent to running the bcdedit /enum active /v command.
segment.target: Running the bcdedit /v command by itself is equivalent to running the bcdedit /enum active /v command.

segment.source: Specifies a one-time display order to be used for the next boot.
segment.target: Specifies a one-time display order to be used for the next boot.

segment.source: This command is similar to the /displayorder option, except that it is used only the next time the computer starts.
segment.target: This command is similar to the /displayorder option, except that it is used only the next time the computer starts.

segment.source: Afterwards, the computer reverts to the original display order.
segment.target: Afterwards, the computer reverts to the original display order.

segment.source: Specifies the default entry that the boot manager selects when the timeout expires.
segment.target: Specifies the default entry that the boot manager selects when the timeout expires.

segment.source: Specifies the display order that the boot manager uses when displaying boot options to a user.
segment.target: Specifies the display order that the boot manager uses when displaying boot options to a user.

segment.source: Specifies the time to wait, in seconds, before the boot manager selects the default entry.
segment.target: Specifies the time to wait, in seconds, before the boot manager selects the default entry.

segment.source: Specifies the display order for the boot manager to use when displaying the Tools menu.
segment.target: Specifies the display order for the boot manager to use when displaying the Tools menu.

segment.source: Enables or disables Emergency Management Services (EMS) for the specified entry.
segment.target: Enables or disables Emergency Management Services (EMS) for the specified entry.

segment.source: Enables or disables EMS for the specified operating system boot entry.
segment.target: Enables or disables EMS for the specified operating system boot entry.

segment.source: Sets the global EMS settings for the computer.
segment.target: Sets the global EMS settings for the computer.

segment.source: /emssettings does not enable or disable EMS for any particular boot entry.
segment.target: /emssettings does not enable or disable EMS for any particular boot entry.

segment.source: Enables or disables the boot debugger for a specified boot entry.
segment.target: Enables or disables the boot debugger for a specified boot entry.

segment.source: Although this command works for any boot entry, it is effective only for boot applications.
segment.target: Although this command works for any boot entry, it is effective only for boot applications.

segment.source: Specifies or displays the global debugger settings for the system.
segment.target: Specifies or displays the global debugger settings for the system.

segment.source: This command does not enable or disable the kernel debugger; use the /debug option for that purpose.
segment.target: This command does not enable or disable the kernel debugger; use the /debug option for that purpose.

segment.source: To set an individual global debugger setting, use the bcdedit /setdbgsettings type value command.
segment.target: To set an individual global debugger setting, use the bcdedit /setdbgsettings type value command.

segment.source: Enables or disables the kernel debugger for a specified boot entry.
segment.target: Enables or disables the kernel debugger for a specified boot entry.

segment.source: To troubleshoot a new installation, enable debug mode by modifying the boot configuration file (BCD).
segment.target: To troubleshoot a new installation, enable debug mode by modifying the boot configuration file (BCD).

segment.source: For example, use the following syntax to enable kernel or boot debug.
segment.target: For example, use the following syntax to enable kernel or boot debug.

segment.source: where id is the GUID of the Loader object that is used to load the operating system.
segment.target: where id is the GUID of the Loader object that is used to load the operating system.

segment.source: "Default" can be used if the operating system is the default option of the Boot Manager menu.
segment.target: "Default" can be used if the operating system is the default option of the Boot Manager menu.

segment.source: For examples of BCDEdit, see Boot Configuration Data in Windows Vista.
segment.target: For examples of BCDEdit, see Boot Configuration Data in Windows Vista.

segment.source: Sets the global remote event logging parameters.
segment.target: Sets the global remote event logging parameters.

segment.source: Enables or disables remote event logging for an operating system entry.
segment.target: Enables or disables remote event logging for an operating system entry.

segment.source: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI
segment.target: BCD System Store Settings for UEFI

segment.source: Boot Configuration Data in Windows Vista
segment.target: Boot Configuration Data in Windows Vista
